reviewText: I had given Shockwave 2004 a five star rating before, wrongly stating that it was the only five star Pride event that I have ever seen. This event is another top notch performance in every way. Every fight on this card is exciting as hell. If you are a fan of MMA and really want to own the most exciting that Pride has to offer, then I highly recommend this DVD along with Shockwave 2004. Buy it!
summary: Ok, so another five star after all...

reviewText: Pride GP Total Elimination 2003 was a tough act to follow with a great MW/LHW tournament. This time, Pride GP brought to you the HW version of the GP and it was a tournament with a pretty stellar crowd. The first ever Grand Prix winner (2000) Mark "the Hammer" Coleman is back to defend the title he won in years past with a field full of up-and-coming fighters as well as the Interim HW Champion Antonio Rodrigo "Minotauro" Nogueira and the HW Champion Fedor Emelianenko.No fight goes to the judges in this event. Suprise finishes, new finishing maneuvers, ground-n-pound, flash knockdowns, and technical ground work made this one of the better Pride events in a very long time. Every fighter on this card was here to advance to the next step in the GP: Critical Countdown 2004.This is a must have MMA DVD for all of you die hard MMA/Pride FC/UFC fans. If you enjoyed Total Elimination 2003, you'll truly enjoy this event. If you enjoy MMA and Pride FC as a whole, you'll love this event.just watch out for that left hook :)fight order:1. Yoshiki Takahashi vs. Heath Herring2. Sergei Kharitonov vs. Murilo "Ninja" Rua3. Paulo Cesar "Giant" Silva vs. Henry "Sentoryu" Miller4. Gan "the Giant" McGee vs. Semmy "Hightower" Schilt5. Stefan "Blitz" Leko vs. Naoya Ogawa6. Mirko "CroCop" Filipovic vs. Kevin "the Monster" Randleman7. Antonio Rodrigo "Minotauro" Nogueira vs. Hirotaka Yokoi8. Mark "the Hammer" Coleman vs. Fedor Emelianenko
summary: great opening to a good tournament

reviewText: Arguably the best thing about Pride Fighting Championships was its yearly sixteen-man Grand Prix tournaments. These tournaments, which began somewhat clumsily in 2000 with the now-legendary open-weight GP, had reached a level of high maturity by the time TOTAL ELIMINATION 2004 kicked off in the Saitama Super Arena in Tokyo on April 24, 2004. Production values for the show were awe-inspiring and exceeded what you'd see even at the most lavish rock concerts, much less a sporting event, but the real draw was, of course, the fighters. Pride's heavyweight division was always much deeper than the UFC's, and while they had to pad the brackets a bit to get to the requisite number, the opening round was nevertheless an impressive assemblage of talent. The bouts were:Fedor Emilianenko vs. Mark "The Hammer" Coleman: This bout pitted Pride's reigning heavyweight champion against its 2000 GP winner, but more than that, it pitted the foremost practitioner of ground 'n pound against the man who is commonly credited for inventing it. A classic matchup of young vs. old lions.Antiono Rodrigo Nogueira vs. Hirotaka Yokoi: Big Nog had an iron chin, great boxing and possessed insanely good grappling skills, but Yokoi had a weapon of his own: the support of every Japanese in the audience. Lots of heart in this fight.Kevin Randelman vs. Mirko Cro Cop: "The Monster," a former UFC heavyweight champion, was pitted against the one-kick knockout power of the Croatian Sensation, a man many figured was the odds-on favorite to win the entire tourney. A shocker.Sergei Kharitonov vs. Ninja Rua: Kharitonov had exploded onto the Pride scene with dominating performances and looked to be the rising star of the heavyweight division, while Ninja had bulked up from middleweight to show he could fight the big boys. This fight is all action and all brutal.Semmy Schilt vs. Gan McGee: Schilt, one of the world's most decorated (and largest) kickboxers, squared off against McGee, a perennial challenger at heavyweight in both the UFC and Pride.Paulo "Giant" Silva vs. Henry Miller: In what might be described as a battle of body types, the 7'2" Giant Silva took on American sumo "Sentoryu" Miller.Naoya Osawa vs. Stefan Leko: Japanese Olympic medalist in judo Osawa was considered the Hope of Japan, while Leko, a decorated German kickboxer, was making his MMA debut.As you can see, there was a load of star power in this card, and while most of the fights went as expected, there was one colossal upset and another fight which featured some of the hardest clean striking to the head and body you are likely to see in a heavyweight fight, as well as vicious KO outcome. There were definitely fighters in the tourney who were simply put in as "warm bodies" but since some of them won their fights, it's hard to say the outcomes were guaranteed. And the Grand Prix format allowed the reigning champion to join the fray without putting his belt on the line, something modern American audiences have trouble understanding, but which was crucial to getting all the best fighters from a division into the same bracket. Bellator's motto today is "where championships are earned not given," and the GP format gave audiences that too-rare opportunity in combat sports, the chance to see the best fight the best to prove who was best of all.
summary: There Can Be Only One - Part One

reviewText: Totally the best tournament to date; definately surpassing the expectations of the middleweight tournament of 2005, and has some of the greatest heavyweights of all time squaring off to see who will be The 2004 Heavyweight Grand Prix Champion. Coleman, Fedor, Randleman, Cro-Cop, and none other than the Texas Crazy Horse Heath Herring all make this one to remember. This tournament continues in Critical Countdown 2004, and what a countdown it is.
Title: N/A

reviewText: WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERSJapan's Pride FC has some of the most talented fighters in mixed martial arts today, and this event is a fine example.  These in particular are all heavyweight fights, and the tournament is a sort of elimination system, in which the winners of every fight advance to the next tournament.  Fights are one 10 minute round, followed by two 5-minute rounds, which I especially like, having gotten into mixed martial arts by way of the UFC.  I've always felt that 3 5-minute rounds just isn't enough time.  Here, the fights have plenty of room to unfold, and only one even goes into the second round.So, as I mentioned, we have here the cream of the martial arts crop.  Chief among them is the incredible Fedor Emelianenko, considered by many to be the best fighter out there today.  Watching his very impressive submission victory (in 2 minutes) over the legendary Mark Coleman, it's certainly not hard to believe.  There are tons of other great fights here as well, such as Sergei Kharitonov pummeling Murilo Rua, wrestler Kevin Randleman scoring a surprise knockout over lethal kickboxer Mirko "Cro Cop" Filipovic, and Antonio Rodrigo Noguera's epic battle against Hirotaka Yokoi.A couple of fights here are kind of more novelty than anything, like the 7-foot Giant Silva taking on the short, squat Henry Miller, and the "giant vs. giant" matchup between Semmy Schilt and Gan McGee, but they're still fun to watch.  Not a single boring fight on here.  Also, Bas Rutten's commentary and interviews are really entertaining, and UFC champ Chuck Liddell even stops by for a little commentary toward the end.All in all, a great buy for Pride fans, and mixed martial arts fans in general.
Title: N/A
